title: France secure spot at 2026 World Cup as Mbappe scores twice against Ukraine
summary: Olise and Ekitike also on target as two-time champions France qualify for 2026 World Cup with 4-0 home win over Ukraine.

title: US pushes Security Council to back Gaza plan as Russia offers counter text
summary: The US mission to the UN warned Palestinians could suffer "grave consequences" if the body did not back its plan soon.

title: LIVE: Ukraine’s capital Kyiv comes under deadly Russian attack
summary: At least four people were killed in the city, according to the country's president.

title: How many times has Israel violated the Gaza ceasefire?
summary: Israeli forces continue to carry out attacks despite the ceasefire in Gaza, where hundreds of people have been killed.

title: Epstein emails with author Wolff raise journalism ethics questions: Experts
summary: While journalists build ties with sources to obtain information, scholars say certain boundaries must be maintained.

title: At least 2 dead, 21 missing in landslides in Indonesia’s Java island
summary: A search and rescue operation is under way to look for the missing victims.

title: ‘Massive enemy attack’: Russia pounds Ukraine’s Kyiv, killing four
summary: President Zelenskyy says dozens also wounded as Moscow launched some 430 drones and 18 missiles.

title: South Africa lets 153 Palestinians disembark following 12-hour plane ordeal
summary: Chartered plane carrying group of Palestinian passengers was second to land in South Africa in recent weeks.

title: Ivory Coast boosts border defence due to ‘unusual flow’ of Malian refugees
summary: Ivorian authorities said the influx of Malian refugees was caused by 'attacks against civilians' from armed groups.

title: Shohei Ohtani, Aaron Judge make history with back-to-back MVPs
summary: Los Angeles Dodgers' Shohei Ohtani wins fourth MLB MVP award while New York Yankees' Aaron Judge bags a third.

title: Will Pakistan’s defence overhaul strengthen or upset its military balance?
summary: Amendment reshapes military command, raising fears of weakened civilian control and diminished autonomy for services.

title: Alcaraz secures year-end world number one ranking at ATP Finals
summary: Carlos Alcaraz beats out Jannik Sinner to number one spot after the Spaniard defeated Lorenzo Musetti in Turin, Italy.

title: Gaza : la dépouille de l'otage Meni Godard a été rendue à Israël par le Hamas
summary: Le Hamas et le Jihad islamique ont rendu jeudi à Gaza la dépouille de l'otage israélien Meni Godard, tué le 7 octobre 2023 à l'âge de 73 ans. De son côté, l'Autorité palestinienne a annoncé que des soldats israéliens avaient tué dans le sud de la Cisjordanie deux adolescents de 15 ans, présentés par l'armée israélienne comme des "terroristes en passe de perpétrer une attaque".

title: Trump a écrit au président israélien pour demander une grâce pour Netanyahu
summary: Dans un courrier adressé au président israélien, Donald Trump a demandé qu'une grâce soit accordée au Premier ministre Benjamin Netanyahu, poursuivi dans son pays pour corruption, a révélé mercredi le bureau de la présidence.

title: Législatives en Irak : le Premier ministre sortant Mohamed Chia al-Soudani revendique la victoire
summary: Après les premiers résultats de la commission électorale donnant sa liste en tête aux législatives, le Premier ministre sortant Mohamed Chia al-Soudani a revendiqué la victoire mardi soir. La formation du prochain gouvernement irakien devrait toutefois donner lieu à d'intenses tractations.

title: Israël rouvre un point de passage "permanent" aux camions d'aide dans le nord de Gaza
summary: Les autorités israéliennes ont annoncé mercredi la réouverture "permanente" du point de passage de Zikim, au nord de la bande de Gaza, pour permettre l'entrée d'aide humanitaire internationale dans le territoire palestinien, ravagé par plus de deux ans de guerre.

title: Mahmoud Abbas à Paris : bientôt des élections ?
summary: Pour sa première visite en France en tant que chef d'État, depuis la reconnaissance de la Palestine par Paris, Mahmoud Abbas s'engage auprès d'Emmanuel Macron sur la tenue d'élections sur l'ensemble des territoires palestiniens. Les dernières datent de près de vingt ans. On va plus loin avec Patricia Allémonière et Melina Huet.

title: Gaza : les combattants du Hamas piégés dans des tunnels à Rafah, un test décisif pour le plan Trump
summary: Le sort de près de 200 combattants du Hamas, retranchés dans des tunnels à Rafah, dans une zone contrôlée par l’armée israélienne, menace de faire voler en éclats le cessez-le-feu à Gaza. Alors que le mouvement islamiste palestinien rejette toute idée de reddition, Washington craint que leur élimination sur ordre d’un Benjamin Netanyahu sous pression empêche toute avancée du plan Trump.

title: Que reste-t-il du Hezbollah ?
summary: Le chef du Hezbollah, Naïm Qassem, a de nouveau affirmé que la milice chiite n’abandonnera pas les armes au Liban. Pour autant, il dit respecter le cessez-le-feu et ne pas avoir tiré sur Israël depuis. Dans les faits, que reste-t-il réellement de l'arsenal du Hezbollah et de son influence ?

title: Israël dit avoir arrêté des colons impliqués dans des violences en Cisjordanie occupée
summary: En Israël, l'armée et la police ont affirmé mardi avoir appréhendé plusieurs civils israéliens ayant attaqué, masqués, des Palestiniens et incendié des biens dans la région de Tulkarem, en Cisjordanie occupée.

title: Rencontre Macron-Abbas : le président palestinien s'engage à organiser des élections
summary: Le président palestinien Mahmoud Abbas s'est engagé mardi à mener des réformes, dont la tenue d'élections, lors de sa rencontre avec Emmanuel Macron à l'Élysée. Le chef de l'État a quant à lui assuré que les projets d'annexion israéliens constituaient une "ligne rouge".

title: Irak : Élections législatives scrutées de près par l'Iran et les États-Unis
summary: Les Irakiens votent mardi pour élire un nouveau Parlement, un scrutin peu susceptible de bouleverser le paysage politique, mais surveillé de près par Téhéran et Washington. Analyse d'Amar Al Hameedawi, grand reporter France 24.

title: Qui sont les groupes armés qui défient le Hamas à Gaza ?
summary: Le cessez-le-feu conclu le 10 octobre entre le Hamas et Israël a mis fin à la guerre ouverte, mais pas à la violence à Gaza. Au moins sept factions armées et clans se battent désormais contre le Hamas. Des images témoignent déjà d’affrontements impliquant ces groupes, dont plusieurs sont soupçonnés d'avoir des liens avec Tel-Aviv.

title: Irak : la défiance dans les urnes ? Parlons-en avec A. Poiret, A. Bakawan et A. Al Hameedawi
summary: C'est de l'Irak dont nous discutons aujourd'hui, alors que sa population est appelée aux urnes pour des élections législatives. Ces dernières années, le pays est passé sous les radars médiatiques. Mais après le cessez-le-feu à Gaza, l’affaiblissement du Hezbollah au Liban, la chute de Bachar Al-Assad en Syrie, les Irakiens voudraient que leur pays retrouve sa voix et sa voie. Est-ce possible, tant l'emprise des milices armées est grande, tout autant que les ingérences américaine et iranienne ?

title: Aux Pays-Bas, une victoire incertaine contre le populisme
summary: Si Rob Jetten, vainqueur d’une courte tête de Geert Wilders et son parti d’extrême droite, a redonné un peu d’espoir face à la progression de formations populistes aux Pays-Bas et en Europe, former une coalition s’annonce très complexe.

title: Boualem Sansal espère arriver en France dans les prochaines heures, selon Kamel Daoud
summary: L’écrivain Kamel Daoud s’est entretenu par téléphone avec son confrère qui a été gracié par le président algérien mercredi. Il avait été condamné à cinq ans de prison pour « atteinte à l’unité nationale ».

title: EN DIRECT, Gaza : Israël dit avoir identifié le corps rendu jeudi soir et confirme qu’il s’agit de celui d’un otage
summary: Le bureau du premier ministre israélien, Benyamin Nétanyahou, a déclaré qu’il s’agit du corps de l’Israélien Meny Godard, tué le 7 octobre 2023 à l’âge de 73 ans.

title: EN DIRECT, guerre en Ukraine : quatre personnes tuées lors de l’attaque massive de Kiev, annonce Volodymyr Zelensky
summary: La capitale ukrainienne a subi une attaque de missiles et de drones russes tôt vendredi, qui a touché huit districts de la capitale sur dix. « Environ 430 drones et 18 missiles ont été utilisés lors de cette frappe », a précisé le président ukrainien.

title: Le travail vu d’Europe : 18 % des travailleurs de l’Union européenne affirment qu’un programme informatique suit leur activité de manière extensive ou partielle
summary: Eurofound, la Fondation européenne pour l’amélioration des conditions de vie et de travail en Europe, a publié, début septembre, les premiers résultats de son enquête « European Working Conditions Survey 2024 ». Cette semaine, « Le Monde » se penche sur la diversité du management algorithmique.

title: Vantara, l’immense zoo privé d’un milliardaire indien qui aspire des animaux du monde entier par milliers
summary: Un rapport international, qui sera examiné le 23 novembre par la Convention sur les espèces menacées d’extinction, met en évidence de nombreuses anomalies dans les transferts massifs de spécimens vers une structure privée du Gujarat, devenue en quelques années le plus grand parc animalier au monde.

title: La question « Chaleur humaine » : Est-ce que l’accord de Paris sur le climat a (vraiment) servi à quelque chose ?
summary: Chaque semaine, l’équipe du podcast Chaleur humaine répond à vos questions sur la transition climatique

title: « Jusqu’où va aller cette folie qui consiste à imaginer qu’en effaçant l’Orchestre philharmonique d’Israël, on va résoudre un problème ? »
summary: Les perturbations entourant un concert de l’Orchestre d’Israël à la Philarmonie de Paris, entre autres exemples récents, le démontrent une nouvelle fois : le fait d’être un créateur ou un intellectuel israélien serait devenu un frein à une invitation à l’étranger, regrette dans sa chronique Michel Guerrin, rédacteur en chef au « Monde ».

title: Michel Feher, philosophe : « Les promoteurs du rassemblement des droites européennes profitent du chemin tracé par Donald Trump »
summary: Dans une tribune au « Monde », Michel Feher s’inquiète des conséquences du trumpisme sur les cultures politiques européennes, et interroge les manières dont les partis de gauche peuvent faire face à cette lame de fond idéologique.

title: Andrew, la déchéance princière du mouton noir des Windsor
summary: Fils préféré de la reine Elizabeth II, le prince Andrew a perdu son titre et ses privilèges après des années d’excès et ses liens avérés avec Jeffrey Epstein, financier américain accusé de crimes sexuels. Une décision du roi Charles III, jugée inévitable pour préserver la monarchie.

title: En Albanie, la jeunesse de Kukës cherche à se bâtir un avenir au Royaume-Uni
summary: Cette ville du nord du pays voit chaque année des milliers de jeunes partir clandestinement pour l’Angleterre. Afin d’endiguer ces départs massifs, la municipalité se mobilise pour la formation et la culture. Même si certains reviennent, déçus par leurs conditions de vie outre-Manche, beaucoup continuent néanmoins de croire au rêve britannique.

title: Aux Etats-Unis, les démocrates s’inspirent des méthodes du monde MAGA pour mieux contrer Donald Trump
summary: Lors d’un rassemblement destiné aux consultants, aux cadres et aux influenceurs progressistes, les démocrates ont mis en avant de nouvelles formes de communication dans une sorte de miroir inversé des raouts républicains Make America Great Again.

title: Israeli forces turn Hebron home into military post amid city raid
summary:
Israeli forces turn Hebron home into military post amid city raid

 Israeli forces raided the southern area of Hebron, deploying military vehicles across several neighbourhoods and streets.

During the operation, they converted a house in the Wadi al-Hossein area into a military post, forcing its residents to leave their home into the open, despite heavy rain.

title: Israeli airstrikes, artillery hit areas inside 'Yellow Line' in Gaza
summary:
Israeli airstrikes, artillery hit areas inside 'Yellow Line' in Gaza

Israeli warplanes carried out airstrikes on Friday inside the “Yellow Line” in the southeastern area of Khan Younis, southern Gaza Strip, according to Al Jazeera.

Meanwhile, Israeli artillery shelled areas inside the “Yellow Line” east of Beit Lahia in northern Gaza.

title: Morning update
summary:
Morning update

Good morning Middle East Eye readers,

Here are the latest updates in Gaza and the occupied West Bank:

  • Three Palestinians were wounded by live Israeli gunfire early on Friday during an Israeli army raid on the town of al-Eizariya, southeast of occupied Jerusalem.

  • UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini has warned that millions of Palestinian refugees are at risk of losing access to essential services unless the agency receives substantial new funding.

  • The mayor of Khan Younis has warned that Gaza has been subjected to what he described as deliberate and systematic destruction, saying that “everything has been destroyed” — including the territory’s natural environment, with an estimated 90 percent of its vegetation wiped out.

  • Palestinian media sources reported that Israeli warplanes carried out airstrikes on the eastern areas of Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.

  •  Israeli forces deployed stun grenades while carrying out a raid in the Old City and surrounding areas in central Nablus, in the northern West Bank.

title: Evening recap
summary:
Evening recap

Our live blog will shortly be closing until tomorrow morning.

Here are the day’s key developments:

- Two Palestinian boys have been shot dead by Israeli forces in Beit Amr, north of Hebron, in the occupied West Bank. Local media have identified them as Mohammed Abu Ayyash and Bilal Baha’a Bouran.

- Israeli settlers set fire to a mosque near the occupied West Bank city of Salfit on Thursday, in the latest attack amid a wave of escalating violence against Palestinians.

- The Israeli army carried out a drone strike targeting a minivan in Toul, a village in the Nabatieh district in Lebanon, wounding one person and leaving unexploded ordnance around the area. Overnight, Israeli forces struck a restaurant in the town of Tayr Filsey in the Sour district, along the Litani River.

- Israel has confirmed receipt of a casket from Gaza that belongs to a deceased Israeli captive. The casket was delivered by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that although he appreciated US President Donald Trump’s letter to President Isaac Herzog urging a pardon, he would not accept it if it required admitting guilt in the corruption case against him.

title: Iran demands United Nations hold Trump responsible for June Israeli air strikes
summary:
Iran demands United Nations hold Trump responsible for June Israeli air strikes

Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi has called for the United Nations to impose "appropriate measures" against the US and Israel over military strikes in June against Iran's nuclear sites.

Araghchi said that President Donald Trump and other US officials bear "criminal responsibility" for the strikes after Trump's statement last week that he directed Israel's initial attack on Iran on 13 June. 

In a letter on Wednesday to UN secretary general Antonio Guterres and the UN Security Council, Araghchi said Israel and the US must be subject to reparations, including restitution and compensation for the damage caused in Iran.

Spokespersons for the US mission to the UN and for Guterres' office did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Trump told reporters on 6 November that he was "very much in charge" of Israel's initial strike on Iran.

- Reporting by Reuters

title: Rubio says Israeli settler violence in West Bank could undermine Gaza peace deal
summary:
Rubio says Israeli settler violence in West Bank could undermine Gaza peace deal

US Secretary of State Marco Rubio became one of the few in the Trump administration to criticise Israeli settler violence in the occupied West Bank after reiterating the Israeli president's and senior military officials' condemnation of recent settler attacks.

Speaking from Hamilton International Airport in Canada on Wednesday after a G7 foreign ministers meeting, Rubio told reporters that he “thought today the comments were very strong by the president of Israel and also by the IDF commander in the area”, referring to an Israeli army official. 

Rubio was referring to Israeli officials' condemnation of an arson attack by dozens of masked Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank villages of Beit Lid and Deir Sharaf on Tuesday. The settlers then went on to attack the Israeli military and the police, who were sent in to stop the violence.

Read more: Rubio says Israeli settler violence in West Bank could undermine Gaza peace deal

title: Rubio says Israeli settler violence in West Bank could undermine Gaza peace deal
summary:
Rubio says Israeli settler violence in West Bank could undermine Gaza peace deal

Submitted by MEE staff on Thu, 11/13/2025 - 18:59
US secretary of state makes a rare statement condemning Israeli settler violence in the occupied West Bank
US Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaks to journalists at the John C Munro Hamilton International Airport after the G7 foreign ministers meeting, in Hamilton, Canada, on 12 November (Mandel Ngan/Reuters)
Off

US Secretary of State Marco Rubio became one of the few in the Trump administration to criticise Israeli settler violence in the occupied West Bank after reiterating the Israeli president's and senior military officials' condemnation of recent settler attacks.

Speaking from Hamilton International Airport in Canada on Wednesday after a G7 foreign ministers meeting, Rubio told reporters that he “thought today the comments were very strong by the president of Israel and also by the IDF commander in the area”, referring to an Israeli army official. 

Rubio was referring to Israeli officials' condemnation of an arson attack by dozens of masked Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank villages of Beit Lid and Deir Sharaf on Tuesday. The settlers then went on to attack the Israeli military and the police, who were sent in to stop the violence.

Several Palestinians were injured, and their property and land were destroyed in the attacks.

Israeli President Isaac Herzog said the attacks were “shocking and serious” and called for authorities to “act decisively to eradicate the phenomenon and to strengthen the IDF fighters and security forces who protect us day and night”.

Army chief Eyal Zamir and senior Israeli military official Major General Avi Bluth also condemned the attacks. 

Bluth, meanwhile, referred to the settlers as “anarchist fringe” who prevented the Israeli military from concentrating on counterterrorism and defence.

It is rare for Israeli politicians or the military to condemn Israeli settler attacks, which have increased to an almost daily basis since the 7 October 2023 Hamas-led attacks on southern Israel and the war on Gaza, which has been recognised as a genocide by the United Nations. 

Condemnations are normally issued when Israeli soldiers are attacked, and the Israeli military has been accused of being "complicit" in settler violence.

While official criticisms pointed to a small fringe, the attacks are widespread. The UN office for the coordination of humanitarian affairs documented 264 incidents of settler violence in the occupied West Bank in October - the highest number of attacks for a month since records began in 2006.

Around 1,500 settler attacks have been recorded this year alone.

While the Biden administration imposed sanctions on a handful of Israeli settlers and settlement-related entities, the Trump administration lifted these sanctions in January. 

Undermining Gaza truce

Rubio also said the US administration would do everything in its power to prevent violence in the occupied West Bank from impacting the Gaza peace deal.

Israeli settlers torch West Bank mosque and spray racist slogans
Read More »

“Certainly there’s some concern about events in the West Bank spilling over and creating an effect that could undermine what we’re doing in Gaza,” he said.  

“We don’t expect it to. We’ll do everything we can to make sure it doesn’t happen.”

His comments came in response to a reporter asking him about whether the “spate of violence in the West Bank” could potentially endanger the current peace plan underway between Israel and Gaza, after Israel’s more than two-year war on the enclave. 

G7 ministers also released a public statement on Wednesday regarding violence in the West Bank,  expressing concern for “the deteriorating security situation”, and said all parties should refrain from actions and statements that “may undermine the prospect of a two-state solution that may undermine the prospect of a two-state solution including Israeli’s expansion of settlements, legalization of settlement outposts and any annexation of the West Bank”. 

“We express our strongest condemnation for the rise in extremist settler violence committed against Palestinians, which undermines security and stability in the West Bank and threatens prospects for a lasting peace,” the statement said.

Israeli settler violence continued on Thursday with settlers setting fire to a mosque in the village of Deir Istiya in the northern occupied West Bank, as well as vandalising walls with racist graffiti. Settlers also used bulldozers to establish and expand a new settlement outpost on Jabal al-Najma in Qaryut. 

Israeli settlements are illegal under international law. 

US Politics
News

Mon, 05/04/2020 - 21:19

title: Israel receives another body of Israeli captive from Gaza
summary:
Israel receives another body of Israeli captive from Gaza

Israel has confirmed receipt of a casket from Gaza on Thursday that belongs to a deceased Israeli captive.

The casket was delivered by the International Committee of the Red Cross, as has been routine.

The body has not yet been identified.

title: Likud MP says ultranationalist rabbi Meir Kahane was right
summary:
Likud MP says ultranationalist rabbi Meir Kahane was right

Submitted by Lubna Masarwa on Thu, 11/13/2025 - 17:54
Nissim Vaturi, who is also Knesset deputy speaker, told MPs that 'Kahane was right in many ways where we were wrong'
Nissim Vaturi is a Knesset member of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud party (Knesset Archive)
Off

The deputy speaker of the Knesset has said that Meir Kahane, an ultranationalist rabbi who called for the expulsion of Palestinians from Israel and whose Kach movement is still banned as a terrorist organisation, was right.

Nissim Vaturi, a member of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud party, made the remarks during a parliamentary debate on Wednesday in which he also criticised former Likud leaders for refusing to engage with Kahane.

Challenged by other MPs that Kahane was a terrorist, and asked if he supported “Jewish terror”, Vaturi replied: “I support it. Believe me, Kahane was right in many ways where we were wrong, where the people of Israel were wrong.”

Likud leaders of the past had been wrong to exclude Kahane, Vaturi continued: “They should have examined the matters and understood one thing: Arabs on our border, terrorists on our border.”

US-born Kahane was himself elected to the Knesset in 1984 after Kach won a single seat in that year’s elections, but found himself ostracised and reviled by his fellow MPs and in wider Israeli political circles.

The US-born rabbi, who also advocated for the creation of a Jewish theocracy, was boycotted by other parties. When Kahane stood up to speak, MPs walked out. Yizhak Shamir, the Likud leader and then-prime minister, denounced him as a “dangerous figure”.

During his single term in parliament, Kahane drafted a series of explicitly racist bills, but these were roundly rejected or ignored.

By the time of the next election in 1988, Kach had been disqualified from Israeli electoral politics on the grounds of inciting racism.

Kahane was shot dead in New York City on 5 November 1990, and his movement was banned as a terrorist organisation in 1994 after one of his adherents, Baruch Goldstein, massacred 29 Palestinians in a killing spree at Hebron’s Ibrahimi Mosque in the occupied West Bank.

'Breeding ground for Kahanists'

Vaturi’s remarks drew condemnation from some Knesset members.

In a post on social media, Naama Lazimi, an MP for the Democrats, said she had appealed to the attorney general and the state attorney to open a criminal investigation into Vaturi for supporting a terrorist organisation.  

“There is a clear line between the escalation of Jewish terror in the territories and the normalisation of Kahane in the Israeli Knesset. Netanyahu has turned the Knesset building into a breeding ground for Kahanists; we will clean it up,” she commented.

Some Likud MPs also criticised Vaturi.

Speaking on Army Radio, Moshe Saada said the former leaders of his party had handled Kahane correctly by ostracising him.

“When he spoke, they left the plenum, because Kahane was not a democrat, was racist, and so he was the exact opposite of Likud’s values,” said Saada.

But Anton Shalhat, the chair of I’lam Media Center, which supports Palestinian journalists working in Israel, told Middle East Eye that Vaturi’s remarks pointed to levels of support within Israel for Kahanist ideology that had long been underestimated or ignored.

“Whenever there is a national confrontation, slogans like 'Kahane was right' appear on the streets,” he said.

“Previously, support for such views was covert and legally prohibited. Now, it has become open and public.”

Israeli minister Ben Gvir visits far-right figurehead Meir Kahane's grave
Read More »

Vaturi’s remarks came just days after two MPs from national security minister Itamar Ben-Gvir’s Kahanist-inspired Jewish Power party, Yitzhak Kroizer and Limor Son Har Melech, participated in a conference marking the 35th anniversary of Kahane’s death.

Extreme right

Ben-Gvir himself is a former member of the Kach movement and avowed admirer of Kahane, who supports the annexation of the West Bank and reportedly once hung a portrait of Goldstein in his home.

Both Kahane and Goldstein have become idealised figures among Israeli far-right settlers, with Goldstein's grave in the illegal settlement of Kiryat Arba frequently visited by settlers during national holidays.

Shalhat said the existence of political parties, such as Jewish Power, formed after Kach was banned but influenced and inspired by Kahanist ideology, was evidence of the movement’s political influence.

“All the ideas Kahane advocated were already widely present across the Israeli political arena. What is new today, however, is that the far right now openly embraces these extremist, populist, and fascist ideas without the slightest sense of shame.”

But a decades-long drift in Israel towards the political far right meant that those once on the margins were now holding positions of power, he said.

“What’s also new is that this camp is hostile not only to Palestinians and Arabs but also to Jews who disagree with them, viewing them as enemies. So, while the ideas themselves are not new, the way they are expressed brazenly and without restraint certainly is.”

Shalhat said that Israeli politics had been moving steadily rightwards since 2000, but this trend had now intensified to the point that it was possible to clearly identify a far-right current, while the traditional right once represented by Likud had effectively disappeared.

“What remains is a centrist bloc leaning slightly to the right, represented by figures like [Benny] Gantz and [Yair] Lapid. Beyond that, the left has all but vanished.”

Inside Israel
Jerusalem
News

Mon, 05/04/2020 - 21:19

title: Israel kills two Palestinian children in occupied West Bank
summary:
Israel kills two Palestinian children in occupied West Bank

Two Palestinian boys have been shot dead by Israeli forces in Beit Amr, north of Hebron, in the occupied West Bank, on Thursday. 

Local media have identified them as Mohammed Abu Ayyash and Bilal Baha'a Bouran. 

In separate statements, both Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) swiftly condemned the killings.

"The occupation's attempts to terrorise the West Bank through systematic killing will fail and will only increase our people's resolve and steadfastness, and strengthen the will to resist," Hamas said.

"We call upon our loyal people in Hebron, and our free and proud people throughout the West Bank, to escalate the resistance, avenge the blood of the martyrs, deter the settlers, and protect our land and holy sites from the terrorism of the occupier."

The PIJ said "the killing of the two martyrs... [and the] withholding of their bodies is a summary execution and a clear war crime".

title: Jeffrey Epstein asked US ambassador to Turkey to 'make him smile' with 'child' photo
summary:
Jeffrey Epstein asked US ambassador to Turkey to 'make him smile' with 'child' photo

Submitted by Sean Mathews on Thu, 11/13/2025 - 16:44
Convicted sex offender Epstein shared thoughts about GPS tracking shoes for children with the head of Dubai Ports World
US ambassador to Turkey and special envoy to Syria Tom Barrack delivers a statement following a meeting with Lebanon's president at the Presidential Palace in Baabda, Lebanon, on 26 August 2025 (Anwar Amro/AFP)
Off

Convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein told current US ambassador to Turkey Tom Barrack to “make me smile” with pictures of him and a “child”, according to a 2016 email that was released in a trove of correspondence by Congress on Wednesday.

“Send photos of you and child.. - make me smile,” Epstein, the disgraced late financier, wrote to Barrack in March 2016.

Epstein then responded to an email from Barrack, writing, “Photos look good.”

It is unclear what "child" Epstein was referring to in his email and what photos were contained in the emails sent by Barrack. 

Barrack had no role with the US government at the time the emails were written. Epstein’s correspondence with Barrack came at a critical time in Barrack's future life and American political history. 

In the spring of 2016, Trump was in a heated presidential race with Hillary Clinton. Around the same time, Barrack was working behind the scenes to introduce his friend, future President Donald Trump, to senior officials from the UAE. Barrack would later go on to chair Trump’s inaugural committee.

Trump has been dogged by his past friendship with Epstein. The US president insists that he cut ties with Epstein around 2004 and 2005, before the disgraced financier became a convicted sex offender. Epstein was found dead in his New York jail cell in 2019. 

Epstein’s correspondence with Barrack shows he maintained close contact with Trump’s trusted advisors years after the future US president says that he cut off contact with him. 

Epstein wrote in a second email to Barrack - “fyi I receive many calls a week about both Donald (L I, beauty contest. mara lago etc) and Clinton from reporters,” he said, adding: “Less so recently with Clinton, but my answers are always I have nothing to say.”

Middle East Eye reached out to the US embassy in Ankara, Turkey, for comment, but did not receive a response by the time of publication.

Longstanding relationships

Barrack, a 78-year-old billionaire real estate investor, is a key figure in Trump’s Middle East foreign policy. In addition to being the ambassador to Turkey, Barrack is the envoy to Syria and has handled diplomacy with Lebanon and the Gulf states.

The email was part of a trove of more than 20,000 pages of documents disclosed on Wednesday by members of the House oversight committee. Barrack was just one of Epstein’s powerful and wealthy contacts, including former President Bill Clinton’s Treasury secretary, Lawrence Summers, billionaire financier Leon Black and Steve Bannon.

From Sykes-Picot to Gaza, Israel redraws borders to impose regional hegemony
Read More »

The email from Epstein to Barrack is notable for several reasons.

Epstein was first convicted of a sexual offence in 2008, meaning his contact with Barrack continued well after that date. At the time Epstein emailed Barrack, the Lebanese-American investor was also deeply involved in Trump’s presidential campaign and exchanging emails with the UAE ambassador to the US, Yousef al-Otaiba. 

Otaiba asked Barrack for information about nominations to lead the US State Department, the CIA and the Defence Department, MEE revealed. 

Barrack's ties to Trump date back to 1988, when he brokered the $400m sale of the Plaza Hotel to Trump. The future US president would later sell the Plaza at a loss to a partnership that included Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal.

Barrack himself moved to Saudi Arabia in the 1970s as a young lawyer. In the subsequent decades, he would forge his own ties with Gulf investors. 

He solicited funds from investors in Abu Dhabi. Barrack’s real estate firm, Colony Capital, began buying tens of thousands of foreclosed single-family homes after the 2008 financial crisis. In 2012, Colony Capital sold the Paris Saint-Germain Football Club, which it had acquired with other investment firms in 2006, to the Qatar Investment Authority. Following Trump’s election, two UAE sovereign wealth funds invested a total of $374m with Barrack.

'Smart' shoes

The trove of emails also shows Epstein’s direct contact with at least one elite citizen of the UAE.

In 2011, Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem, the chairman and CEO of DP World, emailed Epstein about sneakers embedded with GPS tracking devices advertised to monitor children. The email was titled, “Gps GTX Smart Shoe.”

Epstein responded: “thanks, great idea, i really like your friend”.

DP World is a sprawling logistics company owned by Dubai, one of the UAE’s seven emirates.

title: Hamas committed to returning bodies of Israeli captives, spokesperson says
summary:
Hamas committed to returning bodies of Israeli captives, spokesperson says

Hamas representative Hazem Qassem gave assurances on Thursday that the group remains committed to returning the bodies of all Israeli captives in Gaza, per the ceasefire agreement.

"We are continuing to work on the complete handover of the bodies of the Israeli prisoners, despite the difficulties and obstacles... as quickly as possible," he said. 

Hamas has previously said that the scale of destruction in Gaza - and the subsequent  losses it incurred among its ranks that were guarding the Israeli captives - meant locating the bodies has taken longer than expected.
